## Article Summary

**Source:** Appears to be a news article analyzing the 2026 box office landscape and Hollywood's reliance on franchise films. *(Note: The article appears to be cut off at the end.)*

---

### Key Facts & Statistics

- The domestic box office has **not surpassed $10 billion since the pandemic**; the industry is trying to break that mark in 2026 for the first time.
- **2019 benchmark:** $11.4 billion domestically; all top 10 films were IP-driven, nine generated **over $1 billion globally**.
- **Post-pandemic shift:** The top 10 films now represent ~44% of total annual domestic box office (up from ~30% pre-pandemic average).
- **2024:** Only 94 wide releases (2,000+ locations), down 20% from 120 in 2019; box office down ~23% from 2019.
- **2025:** 112 wide releases (~6.6% below 2019 levels); box office still lagged more than 20% vs. 2019.

### Recent Franchise Performance (Named Examples)
- **"Wicked: For Good" (2025):** ~$350M domestic, ~$525M global — underperformed vs. the first film's ~$475M domestic/$750M global. Rotten Tomatoes dropped from 88% to 66%.
- **"Avatar: Fire and Ash" (2025/ongoing):** ~$378.5M domestic, **passed $1 billion internationally** as of the article's writing — but significantly underperformed vs. predecessors.
- **"Avatar: The Way of Water":** $2.3B total; original **"Avatar" (2009):** $2.9B (all-time highest-grossing film).

### 2026 Upcoming Franchise Releases Mentioned
Star Wars, Marvel, DC Comics, Toy Story, Super Mario Bros., Hunger Games, Scream, Scary Movie, Minions, Dune, and Jumanji.

---

### Named Expert Opinions

- **Alicia Reese, SVP Equity Research, Wedbush:** Franchise reliance has become "trickier"; word of mouth matters more; over-stretching franchises (e.g., Marvel post-*Endgame*) leads to failure. Praised Dune as a franchise that successfully balanced core fans and new audiences.
- **Paul Dergarabedian, Head of Marketplace Trends, Comscore:** Studios value audience familiarity with franchise content as a reliable bet.
- **Eric Handler, MD & Senior Research Analyst, Roth Capital Partners:** The box office has been franchise-driven for decades due to audience affinity for known IP.

### Structural Industry Concerns
- Mid-budget films ($15M–$90M) have largely migrated to streaming, reducing theatrical variety.
- Studios and theaters are increasingly **"eventizing"** releases (IMAX, Dolby, merchandise, special events) to drive attendance — a strategy more easily applied to franchise films.
- Consumer home entertainment technology improvements make staying home more attractive.
</Summary>

## Summary: Box Office Report – January 31, 2026 (The Hollywood Reporter)

### Key Box Office Figures (Weekend of ~Jan. 31, 2026)

- **Melania** (documentary, directed by Brett Ratner): Opening to **$8 million or more** domestically from 1,778 theaters — the **best documentary opening in a decade**, surpassing the previous benchmark of $5 million set by Angel Studios' *After Death* (2023). Critics score: **6% on Rotten Tomatoes**; Audience score: **98%; CinemaScore: A**.
- **Send Help** (20th Century, Rachel McAdams/Dylan O'Brien thriller directed by Sam Raimi): Opening to approximately **$16–18 million** domestically; Critics score: 93%, Audience score: 89%.
- **Iron Lung** (indie, directed by YouTuber Markiplier/Mark Fischbach): Also projected to open in the **$16–18 million range**, potentially ahead of *Send Help*.
- **Shelter** (Jason Statham action pic): Coming in on the **low end of expectations at ~$5 million**.
- **Zootopia 2**: Mentioned as a Disney holdover from 2025 holiday season, still in the market.

### Contextual Notes Relevant to the Forecasting Question
- No film mentioned in this article is approaching or near the **$1 billion worldwide threshold**. The article focuses entirely on modest domestic openings in the tens of millions range.
- The largest film referenced, *Zootopia 2*, is a 2025 holdover — its 2026 earnings would need to be tracked separately.
- No indication in this article of any film on a trajectory toward $1 billion before May 1, 2026.

### Other Notable Facts
- Amazon MGM Studios paid **$40 million** in worldwide licensing rights for *Melania* and spent **$35 million** on global marketing — making it the **most expensive documentary in history** by production/acquisition cost.
- *Melania*'s audience skewed heavily conservative and older: **72% of opening-day audience were women over 55**; **78% of all ticket buyers were 55+**.
- The film faced controversy internationally, including a distributor in **South Africa pulling it from release**.
- *Fahrenheit 9/11* remains the all-time top-grossing documentary at **$222 million globally** (not adjusted for inflation) — cited as a historical benchmark.
</Summary>

**2026 Officially Projected To Have The Decade's Best Box Office Yet (Even Without An Avatar Movie)**
